page.title: 14LOCAL HISTORY IN MARSHFIELD
page.content: The name bears no relation to a Marsh, but rather to a March or boundary. In 1264 a charter for a fair to be held annually on 24 May and 24 October was granted to Marshfield, which then became a town. Horses, cattle and sheep were sold. In early days the sheep were penned in what is now called Sheep Fair Lane. There were street stalls by the Crown Inn. The fair was held until 1962. An Avon County Council survey set up in 1982 showed evidence of very early occupation from the Neolithic period through to the Roman period. The Fosse Way is still used as a modern road. The Parish Church of St. Mary was consecrated in 1242. Its present Perpendicular form dates from 1470; it was restored in 1860. There is an active Society which looks at all aspects of local history.
